intro.value: “Karen” is having a moment. You’ve seen her at Red Lobster, taking in a ball game, stuck in traffic, and walking her dog in Central Park.

But how did the name Karen become cultural flashpoint “Karen” — an entitled middle-aged white woman who needs to speak to the manager? According to baby name data from the Social Security Administration (SSA), the name Karen first appeared in the female Top 20 in 1941 and spent 30 years there until it dropped out in 1971. By the 1990s, the name had fallen out of the Top 100.

Chances are you don’t know too many Karens today, but when the name hit it’s peak at #3 in 1965, Karens were everywhere. It’s this swift decay in popularity that’s made the name Karen so era defining (like Patricia before her, and Shirley before her) and that’s why the name has found new notoriety as a pejorative meme. “Karen” has become the perfect caricature of women of a certain age and a certain privilege.
Charting the name’s trajectory got us thinking: are there other names that are equally as “Karen” as Karen?

First we gathered baby names from 1918–2018. Then we dropped any name that never made it to the Top 20 (to account for popularity) and didn’t appear in the top list at least half of the years, or 50 out of 100 (to account for longevity). That left us with 129 female names and 76 male names (yes, we’re going there too!) to test correlation. Correlation works on a scale from -1 to : -1 is a perfect negative correlation, 0 has no correlation, and 1 is a perfect position correlation. otherMKarens.value: Male “Karens” The name Karen is largely reserved for women (especially white women), but is there a male equivalent? Maybe it’s Ian, like Urban Dictionary suggests. Or maybe it’s Rand of Middle Class Fancy fame. Or maybe it’s Donald, the “Karen in Chief.” Or maybe it’s simply Greg. Wrong, it’s definitely one of these names.

compare.value: Now you know which names have the potential to become tomorrow’s next viral punchline, but what about the next generation of “Karens.” Is it really Becky?

Looking ahead 10, 20, and 30 years, we’ve calculated which names have a similar trajectory and strong correlation to the name Karen. Of course, you have the power to determine how your name gets remembered and memed, but it requires us all to put in the work to address institutional and systemic racism, classism, sexism, and privilege.

methods.value: Baby name data for the last 100 years (1918–2018) was collected from the Social Security Administration (SSA). Baby names are classified by sex in the original data, but the authors would like to acknowledge that sex and gender are interwined and do not exist in a male-female binary. See more background on the baby names dataset’s limitations here.

First, for each sex we normalized each year’s name counts by the sex-specific number of babies born in total for each year. This makes sure that any underlying trends in either number of babies or number of babies of a particular sex do not get confused with a trend in name popularity.

Then we needed to see which names had a similar trajectory of popularity over time as the name Karen. There are a variety of ways to calculate a correlation between two groups. We use the Kendall rank correlation coefficient to find the other “Karens.” It measures the similarity of two sets of data based on each data point’s rank when ordered per group.

For example, take the name Karen’s popularity values k_1 and k_2 for two years and another name’s popularity values p_1 and p_2 for the same two years. If the rank of the values k_1 and p_1 are both bigger than the rank of k_2 and p_2 then this is evidence that the ordering of the datasets are similar, increasing the value of the correlations.

This correlation type results in high correlations between two names that have a similar shape of popularity trajectory over time rather than just focusing on their absolute popularity. That is why you see high correlations between the names Karen and Kathy despite Kathy having an overall popularity that is smaller than Karen.

To find future “Karens” we use the same correlation calculation, but we introduce a lag between the popularity trajectories. Names were dropped if this lag caused us to go too far forward in time. If we shift the “Karen” trajectory forward in time and compare it to the other names’ untouched trajectories, we can see which name has a similar popularity curve that is just pushed further into the future.
